In Julia, Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

You can use the `DateTime` module provided by Julia to parse and manipulate date-time information. Here's how you could define a function that does what is asked in your problem statement:

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map(d -> year(d)*100 + month(d), df.dt)
end
```
In this function, we use the `map` function to apply a function on every element in the column `dt` of the DataFrame `df`. This function extracts the year and month from each date-time using the `year` and `month` functions from the `Dates` module respectively. It then converts these two integers into one integer in the format "yyyymm".

To use this function, you would call it as follows:
```julia
add_yearmonth(df)
```
